context: The Raiders sacked Goff only once, on a play during which Bruce Irvin forced a fumble. Other than that, the Oakland defense could put almost no pressure on Goff. The absence of Mack, the former NFL Defensive Player of the Year, was glaring. In the first half Sunday night, Mack had a sack, a forced fumble, a fumble recovery, an interception, and a touchdown on defense. He and the Bears could not sustain that, and they succumbed to the second-half exploits of Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers. But Mack reinforced what a game-changing, difference-making player he is. He left little doubt that he is worth the six-year, $141 million contract given to him by the Bears, making him the league's highest-paid defensive player. [The NFL teams that have serious reasons to worry, versus the ones that don't] Mack, while still with the Raiders, had been holding out, seeking such a deal. The Raiders didn't want to give it to him. They have a $125 million quarterback in Carr. They have a $100 million coach in Gruden. They drew the line at handing out another mammoth deal, not wanting to further strain their budget or push the boundaries of the salary cap. They regarded the king's ransom of draft picks put forth by the Bears, including a pair of first-rounders, as an offer they couldn't refuse. In truth, they could have refused it.

context: The Raiders sacked Goff only once, on a play during which Bruce Irvin forced a fumble. Other than that, the Oakland defense could put almost no pressure on Goff. The absence of Mack, the former NFL Defensive Player of the Year, was glaring. In the first half Sunday night, Mack had a sack, a forced fumble, a fumble recovery, an interception, and a touchdown on defense. He and the Bears could not sustain that, and they succumbed to the second-half exploits of Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers. But Mack reinforced what a game-changing, difference-making player he is. He left little doubt that he is worth the six-year, $141 million contract given to him by the Bears, making him the league's highest-paid defensive player. [The NFL teams that have serious reasons to worry, versus the ones that don't] Mack, while still with the Raiders, had been holding out, seeking such a deal. The Raiders didn't want to give it to him. They have a $125 million quarterback in Carr. They have a $100 million coach in Gruden. They drew the line at handing out another mammoth deal, not wanting to further strain their budget or push the boundaries of the salary cap. They regarded the king's ransom of draft picks put forth by the Bears, including a pair of first-rounders, as an offer they couldn't refuse. In truth, they could have refused it.

source: Hi there, how's it going?<|endoftext|>It's going great! Which do you prefer, football or baseball?<|endoftext|>Oh, I guess baseball. Although I don't have time to see many games anymore.<|endoftext|>Baseball is the American pastime. Japanese are surprised to discover this fact.<|endoftext|>Yeah, I guess they see it as being their own. They have their own fan culture around it. What is your favorite sport?<|endoftext|>I like both baseball and football, but I usually follow them around playoff time. Don't have much time for games.<|endoftext|>Yeah, the seasons are so long that it's tough to get really immersed. Especially baseball. It's what, 162 games?<|endoftext|>162, plus playoffs. Soon they'll be playing until Christmas. Until 2005, a married couple scheduled all the games for the MLB. They must have had special software or something.<|endoftext|>Yeah, although I think they had done it since the 80s. Maybe they did the first few seasons on a Commodore 64 lol?<|endoftext|>The old C64! Classic. I don't remember any good sports games on that though. Football, baseball, soccer. Probably not easy to do on a C64.<|endoftext|>Yeah, I know they had accounting software lol, my dad used it. We had the Minnesota Fats pool game and I think one soccer one. But it was such a different era. No Madden style graphics.<|endoftext|>I wonder whether they had a version of kickball on the C64. The Canadians call the game soccer-baseball.<|endoftext|>Yeah, I've read that somewhere. When I was a kid, we played a kind of kickball called rounders at camp. Our counselor was English. He kept telling us "Run to fourth!" and we were like, "You mean home? Run home?"<|endoftext|>Baseball is American! I don't know what the English would want with it. I bet the English don't collect "Rounders" cards the way we collect baseball cards.<|endoftext|>Right? I wonder if they have cricket cards lol? I think they have stickers for soccer.<|endoftext|>Some guy found $3 million dollars of baseball cards from the 1900s. I wonder what he did with the money.<|endoftext|>Yeah, that's an amazing find. I heard they had been hidden since the 40s.<|endoftext|>Thanks, Grandpa! I bet Grandpa wishes he had cashed them in before he cashed out.

Do you follow football?<|endoftext|>Sorry, I can't say that I do, I'm familiar with the big stories, but that is it.<|endoftext|>That is about how much I know, just the basics, and some fun trivia.<|endoftext|>I used to live in DC so I kind of know the Redskins, but Alex Smith is new to me, is he the quarterback?<|endoftext|>Yes. He took so many AP classes in high school he entered college as a junior, he started working on a master's then.<|endoftext|>Now that is impressive, you have this impression of sports players as jocks, but he transcends that stereotype.<|endoftext|>He really does, he was drafted as a number one pick in 2005 too.<|endoftext|>Do you go to football games? I've been to one once in my life at Indiana University.<|endoftext|>I've been to quite a few at Florida State, but no pro games. There is only 11 minutes of live action anyway.<|endoftext|>I think that is what puts me off, I really don't have time to sit in front of the TV for three hours, and then for only 11 minutes of play.<|endoftext|>It is hard to find time for that, I don't know how some people do it all day, on a weekly basis.<|endoftext|>I guess some people listen to games on the radio, difficult to see how that works.<|endoftext|>I've done it traveling, you've got to really know the team and all of the players' names. It was so much harder.<|endoftext|>Do you have a favorite NFL team. Like I said, I lived in DC for a while so kind of follow them. Now in northern Ohio, the Browns are a difficult team to support.<|endoftext|>I feel you there, living in Florida here. Dolphins are hard to root for and feel proud.<|endoftext|>It could be worse, I read about this team that lost 220-0. It would be hard to watch to the end.

source: Did you know that there was a moral panic in the 1700's because everyone was reading books? Haha.<|endoftext|>I didn't know that lol. We sure are close to a moral panic with all the tablets and social media kids and adults are using.<|endoftext|>Haha, yeah, if people started reading a lot in this day and age society would think that was a wonderful thing! Haha<|endoftext|>Yeah, that would be great, literature is getting lost and great authors like CS Lewis and Tolkien are getting forgotten.<|endoftext|>Right, I think it's funny though that they used to read off bad poetry and whoever laughed first would lose, that's hilarious<|endoftext|>That is hilarious. I wonder who is the champion among them lol. Do you personally like to read?<|endoftext|>I can't say that I do no, I do like audiobooks, I did try to speed read once but I found I didn't retain any information from it, that's why I don't know what to make of the speed reading champion with 4,700 words per minute.<|endoftext|>I wonder how they measure that, I can just skip pages and tell everybody that I read the content, I bet I could read 6000 words per minute that way<|endoftext|>Ya exactly, if I could just flip through pages I could speed read too, what is weird is Starship Troopers is on the military's reading list, idk about the book but the movie is definitely not pro-military<|endoftext|>I guess that's because books aren't as good as movies, a lot of info is missing, the Ender's Game book is also another recommendation for armed forces around the globe<|endoftext|>Ya, did you ever see that movie? I saw it and I like Harrison Ford who is in it, but it was pretty bad in my opinion<|endoftext|>I did see the movie, I thought it was bad as well, I liked the book better, I like reading you can learn many interesting facts, like why the area code of New York is 212. <|endoftext|>Ya I think it was because that was the fastest number that you could dial with a rotary phone? Crazy how that stuff carries over until even today!!<|endoftext|>It is! There's a lot things we need to discover still though, I'm kind of worried the cables carrying phone and internet are underwater, at least some of them.<|endoftext|>Ya it's only about 3 inches thick, I wonder how it is protected? Is it just a cable or are there safeguards in place in case like a ship sinks and crushes it, etc.
context: Til - The trunk of your car is called that because old cars used to have wooden trunks on the back.

Do you like music?<|endoftext|>Very much, I was so excited to learn that "/Hybrid Theory" from Linkin Park has been the best selling album in the 21st century!!<|endoftext|>Did you ever have any cassette tapes?<|endoftext|>Yes, I had many and also vinyls and the CDs.<|endoftext|>What did you do with all of those items? I just threw away my CDs about a month ago, at least the crappy ones.<|endoftext|>I even remember the 78 RPM records, and I loved the books they came in, they were sort of photograph albums, with artist's pictures, it was really cool!<|endoftext|>I wish the music had that today. I remember reading the CD jackets as soon as I got them. I can remember checking out artists mentioned in my favorite albums.<|endoftext|>That was a beautiful part of it. system_output: So in your opinion, there will be more "homegrown" celebrities and less Hollywood stars? You could be right, Hollywood seems less and less connected to its public.
source: Do you still use a landline? <|endoftext|>No. In my opinion, the landline is going extinct. Growing up my grandparents had a multi-party line. My parents had a landline. I killed the landline once cellular was cost effective. Now cellphones are small computers that do so much more than landlines. <|endoftext|>Yeah, an iPhone has more computing power than a mainframe of the 60s. But data still travels best in cables. <|endoftext|>Even on cellular networks, it still travels via cable, except for the last leg. Could you imagine the atmospheric distortion of the signal if data was transmitted from the East to West Coast solely via the airways? <|endoftext|>We would be still at the era of ham radios and telegram. There would be less pictures. <|endoftext|>Less pictures and more garbled messages. Imagine how YouTube videos would look with atmospheric distortion; probably like the picture on old-time TVs with rabbit ear antennas? <|endoftext|>YouTube would be like a TV station, showing only clip to everyone at the same time. I think it would be less popular. <|endoftext|>True. Do you subscribe to any YouTube channels or follow any YouTube celebrities? <|endoftext|>I subscribe to some educational channels. But I don't follow any celebrities, but I hear of them often. <|endoftext|>I used to subscribe to certain hunting/fishing equipment YouTube channels, but found temptation to buy the latest thing to be unproductive. I do like "how to" videos on YouTube. Given that YouTube is accessible to anyone with a computer, being a star has nothing to do with how good your Hollywood agent is and more with establishing a populist following. <|endoftext|>It is more diverse but celebrities still have an advantage on YouTube, being a search engine, popular results get more visibility. <|endoftext|>Agreed. It is a bit art/a bit science in figuring out how to get your videos promoted in the search results. Or, hire an expert who will flood your videos with fictional views to promote its popularity. But established names also help. Judge Judy makes $123k per TV episode; with that amount of draw, her YouTube channel can't help but be a success. <|endoftext|>Do you think $123,000 per episode is too much for her? <|endoftext|>I do not watch her, so I cannot judge. It is one of the few areas where free market economics still reigns. So, if they feel she's worth it, then it's not my place to judge. But that type of draw opens up other markets. For example, Carol Burnett was the first celeb on Sesame Street. <|endoftext|>It was the 70s, she was the star at that time, it makes sense. I wonder if YouTube will have a lasting impact on the star system or this YouTubers thing is just a phase. <|endoftext|>It is definitely here to stay if not expanding. In the early days, you needed a good freestanding camera to make a good video. Today, most cell phones have a good enough camera to make YouTube videos. Some high-end phones can shoot videos almost indistinguishable from freestanding cameras.
context: Pixar Studio has a secret room that is visited often by celebrities.

source: Do you still use a landline? <|endoftext|>No. In my opinion, the landline is going extinct. Growing up my grandparents had a multi-party line. My parents had a landline. I killed the landline once cellular was cost effective. Now cellphones are small computers that do so much more than landlines. <|endoftext|>Yeah, an iPhone has more computing power than a mainframe of the 60s. But data still travels best in cables. <|endoftext|>Even on cellular networks, it still travels via cable, except for the last leg. Could you imagine the atmospheric distortion of the signal if data was transmitted from the East to West Coast solely via the airways? <|endoftext|>We would be still at the era of ham radios and telegram. There would be less pictures. <|endoftext|>Less pictures and more garbled messages. Imagine how YouTube videos would look with atmospheric distortion; probably like the picture on old-time TVs with rabbit ear antennas? <|endoftext|>YouTube would be like a TV station, showing only clip to everyone at the same time. I think it would be less popular. <|endoftext|>True. Do you subscribe to any YouTube channels or follow any YouTube celebrities? <|endoftext|>I subscribe to some educational channels. But I don't follow any celebrities, but I hear of them often. <|endoftext|>I used to subscribe to certain hunting/fishing equipment YouTube channels, but found temptation to buy the latest thing to be unproductive. I do like "how to" videos on YouTube. Given that YouTube is accessible to anyone with a computer, being a star has nothing to do with how good your Hollywood agent is and more with establishing a populist following. <|endoftext|>It is more diverse but celebrities still have an advantage on YouTube, being a search engine, popular results get more visibility. <|endoftext|>Agreed. It is a bit art/a bit science in figuring out how to get your videos promoted in the search results. Or, hire an expert who will flood your videos with fictional views to promote its popularity. But established names also help. Judge Judy makes $123k per TV episode; with that amount of draw, her YouTube channel can't help but be a success. <|endoftext|>Do you think $123,000 per episode is too much for her? <|endoftext|>I do not watch her, so I cannot judge. system_output: Probably only if they step in and play the game. I've never seen any of them do it, but that would be an interesting thing to see.
source: Have you heard of Doug Harey?<|endoftext|>Wasn't he an umpire for the MLB?<|endoftext|>Yes, he just died at 87 years of age.<|endoftext|>I guess he was a big deal, and he lived quite a while. He'll be missed though<|endoftext|>He must've been an interesting character to earn the nickname 'God'.<|endoftext|>He was one of those umpires that knew what he was doing<|endoftext|>Yup, he earned his spot in the Hall of Fame after calling 4,673 games.<|endoftext|>And five World Series, which is a big leagues in the MLB. He wasn't intimidated by anyone, it seems<|endoftext|>He was around to see some of the first World Series that first started in 1903.<|endoftext|>That's incredible! Do you pay attention to baseball much?<|endoftext|>No, I did when I was younger but lost interest. How bout you?<|endoftext|>Every once in a while. It's one of those sports I would rather play than watch. The Japanese are such big fans of baseball that they would probably take the name "national pastime" from the Americans if they could<|endoftext|>Yeah, they are usually surprised to find so many Americans like it too.<|endoftext|>Enough that people used to collect baseball cards. One man found a collection in his grandfather's attic that was worth three million dollars<|endoftext|>That's a lot of money. Are any managers' cards worth anything? They do wear the uniform after all.
context: Doug Harvey, a Major League Baseball umpire for 31 years whose calls of balls or strikes, fair or foul, safe or out were delivered with such gusto and authority that he was known as "God" to thousands of ballplayers, died Jan. 13 in Visalia, Calif. He was 87. Major League Baseball announced the death but did not disclose the cause. According to media accounts, he had battled throat cancer in the 1990s and later had several strokes. Mr. Harvey worked 4,673 ballgames from 1962 to 1992, MLB said, including five World Series, nine National League Championship Series and six All-Star Games. For 18 years, he was an umpiring crew chief. Hundreds of thousands of times he made on-the-spot calls on whether a runner had reached base a millisecond before a throw from a fielder, or whether a pitched ball traveling 90 mph had grazed the veneer of a loosely defined strike zone or missed altogether. The outcome of baseball championships rested on such rulings. Players and fans held strong and differing opinions on what the umpire saw, and they were not shy about telling him when they saw it differently. In 2009, Doug Harvey, right, jokes about throwing former St. Louis Cardinals manager Whitey Herzog out of a game. (Michael Conroy/AP) To Mr. Harvey, arguments with the umpires were a part of the game, but there were limits and there could be no doubt about who was boss. "I would listen for 20 seconds," he once told The New York Times. "I would count to 20 to myself. And I would listen to everything you had to say."

context: Doug Harvey, a Major League Baseball umpire for 31 years whose calls of balls or strikes, fair or foul, safe or out were delivered with such gusto and authority that he was known as "God" to thousands of ballplayers, died Jan. 13 in Visalia, Calif. He was 87. Major League Baseball announced the death but did not disclose the cause. According to media accounts, he had battled throat cancer in the 1990s and later had several strokes. Mr. Harvey worked 4,673 ballgames from 1962 to 1992, MLB said, including five World Series, nine National League Championship Series and six All-Star Games. For 18 years, he was an umpiring crew chief. Hundreds of thousands of times he made on-the-spot calls on whether a runner had reached base a millisecond before a throw from a fielder, or whether a pitched ball traveling 90 mph had grazed the veneer of a loosely defined strike zone or missed altogether. The outcome of baseball championships rested on such rulings. Players and fans held strong and differing opinions on what the umpire saw, and they were not shy about telling him when they saw it differently. In 2009, Doug Harvey, right, jokes about throwing former St. Louis Cardinals manager Whitey Herzog out of a game. (Michael Conroy/AP) To Mr. Harvey, arguments with the umpires were a part of the game, but there were limits and there could be no doubt about who was boss. "I would listen for 20 seconds," he once told The New York Times. "I would count to 20 to myself. And I would listen to everything you had to say."

He'll be missed though<|endoftext|>He must've been an interesting character to earn the nickname 'God'.<|endoftext|>He was one of those umpires that knew what he was doing<|endoftext|>Yup, he earned his spot in the Hall of Fame after calling 4,673 games.<|endoftext|>And five World Series, which is a big leagues in the MLB. He wasn't intimidated by anyone, it seems<|endoftext|>He was around to see some of the first World Series that first started in 1903.<|endoftext|>That's incredible! Do you pay attention to baseball much?<|endoftext|>No, I did when I was younger but lost interest. How bout you?<|endoftext|>Every once in a while. It's one of those sports I would rather play than watch. The Japanese are such big fans of baseball that they would probably take the name "national pastime" from the Americans if they could<|endoftext|>Yeah, they are usually surprised to find so many Americans like it too.<|endoftext|>Enough that people used to collect baseball cards. One man found a collection in his grandfather's attic that was worth three million dollars<|endoftext|>That's a lot of money. Are any managers' cards worth anything? They do wear the uniform after all.
context: Doug Harvey, a Major League Baseball umpire for 31 years whose calls of balls or strikes, fair or foul, safe or out were delivered with such gusto and authority that he was known as "God" to thousands of ballplayers, died Jan. 13 in Visalia, Calif. He was 87. Major League Baseball announced the death but did not disclose the cause. According to media accounts, he had battled throat cancer in the 1990s and later had several strokes. Mr. Harvey worked 4,673 ballgames from 1962 to 1992, MLB said, including five World Series, nine National League Championship Series and six All-Star Games. For 18 years, he was an umpiring crew chief. Hundreds of thousands of times he made on-the-spot calls on whether a runner had reached base a millisecond before a throw from a fielder, or whether a pitched ball traveling 90 mph had grazed the veneer of a loosely defined strike zone or missed altogether. The outcome of baseball championships rested on such rulings. Players and fans held strong and differing opinions on what the umpire saw, and they were not shy about telling him when they saw it differently. In 2009, Doug Harvey, right, jokes about throwing former St. Louis Cardinals manager Whitey Herzog out of a game. (Michael Conroy/AP) To Mr. Harvey, arguments with the umpires were a part of the game, but there were limits and there could be no doubt about who was boss. "I would listen for 20 seconds," he once told The New York Times. "I would count to 20 to myself. And I would listen to everything you had to say."

context: Baseball managers wear uniforms because they are technically able to play for their teams if the need arises.

context: Baseball managers wear uniforms because they are technically able to play for their teams if the need arises.

source: Hello, how are you today? Do you like to go to concerts?<|endoftext|>Not as much as I used to but I do.<|endoftext|>Yeah, same here! Creed gave a concert so bad there were lawsuits against the band.<|endoftext|>Ha ha. I hate to see bad things happen to people but as someone who is not a Creed fan I find that hilarious.<|endoftext|>I don't know much about that band. The sound in the ancient Roman amphitheater must be good for Pink Floyd to record in it without an audience.<|endoftext|>I wonder why they did that. It would be such a beautiful place to be an audience member.<|endoftext|>Yes, I like the live albums. The ancient Roman amphitheatre still has concerts.<|endoftext|>Oh wow. Are you familiar with Lou Reed?<|endoftext|>Yes, I am. I have heard a few of his songs.<|endoftext|>In 2010 he and his wife held a high frequency concert for dogs. What an odd thing to do.<|endoftext|>Oh wow! Really, did the dogs like it? Was it recorded?<|endoftext|>I have no idea. I'm sure that someone has video of it. Do you enjoy the music of the Foo Fighters<|endoftext|>Oh yes, I love them. I love the video of all the drummers and other instruments playing at the same time. People came from all over the world to be in that.<|endoftext|>They are pretty amazing. They performed a concert so loud that it showed up on New Zealand's seismic monitors!
context: In 2002, a Creed concert was so bad that four concert-goers filed a lawsuit against the band.

system_output: I wonder if most of those guys were good at Halo. There was a QB in the NFL named Brad Johnson, and he's the only one who has thrown a touchdown pass to himself.
source: Have you heard that people draft contestants for fantasy spelling bee? Pretty amazing to me.<|endoftext|>I'm not even sure how they would even know that. Aren't all the contestants children?<|endoftext|>Yes. I guess they see how well they won the regional contests.<|endoftext|>I mean, I guess fantasy is for the hardcore fans. Have you ever seen The Lord of the Rings?<|endoftext|>Yes. Of course, that is fantasy of a different type.<|endoftext|>The third movie was the only fantasy film to win an Academy Award for "Best Picture." I did not remember that. Back to competitive fantasy. There is also a game where people draft congresspeople and score on how many bills they successfully vote for. That seems so boring!<|endoftext|>I'm sure political science students would find enjoyment in that. It could be a great teaching tool!<|endoftext|>Yes. But one would really have to dig deeply to keep score. Most news is about when Congress cannot agree. There is a fold in the brain that is the only thing that allows us to tell the difference between fantasy and reality.<|endoftext|>That's an important fold! I wonder how well students tell the difference if they're enrolled in the university that has science fiction courses.<|endoftext|>If I lost the fold, I would probably die jumping off a roof being sure I could fly. Otherwise, my "reality" would be pretty good since I don't dream or daydream bad things. Those students would probably encounter some monsters.<|endoftext|>There's even a concentration in Tolkien studies. That would be interesting<|endoftext|>It sure would. In fantasy football, one of the most important selections is QB since the QB touches the ball on most every play.<|endoftext|>I've never played fantasy football, but I wonder if Kellan Moore is a good contender in that since he's a lefty<|endoftext|>There is talent and luck in fantasy football. I am sure that Moore has had some good games and some poor ones. Alex Smith took so many AP tests in high school that he entered college as a junior.<|endoftext|>He's pretty smart. It would take a lot of AP courses to knock out the first two years of college like that<|endoftext|>It sure would. Of course, QBs need to be somewhat smart. Baker Mayfield, who won the Heisman at Oklahoma University, almost quit football to go into competitive gaming. He could beat the entire team in Halo 3.
context: Superbowl winning quarterback, Brad Johnson, is the only quarterback in NFL history to throw a touchdown pass... to himself.

source: I know Brady can occasionally blow it but he didn't for me. I'm a Chiefs fan...<|endoftext|>Even as a Chiefs fan, do you think that Tom Brady is the greatest quarterback of all time, as he is commonly referred to.<|endoftext|>He's one of the best for sure. I go back to Johnny Unitas as a kid so that's a tough call. All kinds of variables like Kellan Moore being left-handed.<|endoftext|>Apparently, Kellan Moore is the only left-handed quarterback in the NFL, I wonder if the defensive plays factor in that fact and are adjusted.<|endoftext|>Probably, maybe it's like baseball and pitchers and batters play R/L-handedness. Speaking of Brady, I didn't know he played at U of Michigan.<|endoftext|>Yeah, could be to the team's advantage. Yeah, I didn't know that, did Brady play at UMICH on a scholarship?<|endoftext|>Probably... he was a 6th round draft pick in 2000. I do like Boston but I'm not sure I've ever been to Foxborough where the Pat's play. <|endoftext|>Me neither but the Gillette Stadium in Foxborough seems like a giant stadium. Have you ever seen a live professional football game? <|endoftext|>Yes, the Falcons and the Chiefs. I like college better, like Georgia Tech. They could use a Brady QB however... <|endoftext|>Haha, I agree, I really enjoy going to college football games. Although I never knew that the huddle was created by a deaf quarterback so other teams could not read his hand signals. <|endoftext|>Didn't know that either... I thought it was because they couldn't hear. QB's have to scream to be heard in most stadiums. Some QBs are smart like Alex Smith who got a bachelor's in 2 years. <|endoftext|>That's surprising, it seems like the focus on athletes isn't about school but rather heavy emphasis on sports so to see him go on to get his master's degree, is very surprising to me. <|endoftext|>I agree but some are both jocks and academics. I wonder if Brady was? I do admire him, he's seen hard times like the 41-33 loss to the Eagles. <|endoftext|>I definitely think that his leadership and tenacity and the so-called "Patriot Way" can really shape people and lead them to their championships but his wife makes more than double Brady's salary! I thought she was retired!

source: Hi, how are you?<|endoftext|>I am good, thank you. I enjoy travel. Do you?<|endoftext|>I do but I am a worrying traveler. Where is the best place you have been to? <|endoftext|>I have not been out of the country but several places in the country. I like Chicago a lot. Did you know that all of Japan's highways are tolls? <|endoftext|>That's gotta be expensive! What's the best place in Chicago? Where should I go when I visit? <|endoftext|>I like the Natural History Museum and Millennium Park. Lou Malnati's has amazing pizza. It is very expensive to travel in Japan. It costs more than $300 to travel across the country. <|endoftext|>That's a lot. I cannot imagine having to pay that in tolls. I do like Lou's pizza. Have you been to Wrigley Field? I should ask first if you are a baseball fan... <|endoftext|>I have not. We did stop outside of Soldier Field but didn't get to go in. Did you know that Iceland has no public rail service? <|endoftext|>That's odd. Soldier Field is just ok. The Shedd is really good though. Where else, besides Chicago, do you like going? <|endoftext|>I enjoyed the mountains of Tennessee. They are beautiful. We got a cabin with an amazing view. I would go to a lot more places if you could get there faster. The Dutch are working on that. They are creating a commuter bus that goes 160 mph. That would be great. <|endoftext|>Can you imagine the movie Speed on that bus!!!! Holy smokes! <|endoftext|>Ha ha, yes that would change that movie quite a bit. Back to Iceland, most don't have cars and travel between towns by flight! <|endoftext|>Really. Seems a little overkill but what do I know... I want to go there and see the Northern Lights someday. <|endoftext|>That would be a beautiful sight. Off topic but how do you feel about sharks? <|endoftext|>I'm for 'em! <|endoftext|>They are very interesting. Did you know that they don't have rib cages?
context: No fact

source: Hello, how are you doing? Do you like XXXTentacion?<|endoftext|>I never heard of him. I understand that he had been fatally shot. How sad.<|endoftext|>That is sad. I've heard of him too, but never listened to the music.<|endoftext|>Apparently he had a number 1 hit posthumously.<|endoftext|>Right and then more of his songs entered the top 100. These eight are "Moonlight" at No. 16, "Changes" at No. 18, "Jocelyn Flores" at No. 19, one with an unprintable title at No. 28, "Everybody Dies on Their Nightmares" at No. 42, "The Remedy for a Broke Heart (Why Am I So in Love)" at No. 58, "Hope" at No. 80, and "Numb" at No. 82.<|endoftext|>Wow. That's incredible. The lines of his song were sad talking about suicide.<|endoftext|>Seems like a lot of musicians and actor/actress' suffer from some kind of ailment. It's so sad.<|endoftext|>They've got talent but problems. The year B.I.G. was killed his anthem raced up the charts.<|endoftext|>Yeah. That's crazy when people pass away that they get a boost of recognition for their work. Rapper Tupac Shakur's music is in the Library of Congress of "cultural significance."<|endoftext|>It takes death for things to happen and people realize the talent. When Prince died his sales went up.<|endoftext|>Absolutely kinda like a last tribute to them. Before he became a rapper, Eminem's true dream was to become a comic.<|endoftext|>Funny. Did you know McDonalds payed rappers $5 for every time they referenced Big Macs in songs?<|endoftext|>What! That's amazing. Haha rapper Busta Rhymes voiced the Reptar Wagon in the 1998 Rugrats movie.<|endoftext|>That's cool! Did you also know that there is a deaf rapper who rhymes in sign language. That is awesome.<|endoftext|>Some rappers have a sign language translator on stage with them. I've seen it on YouTube!<|endoftext|>That's great! The world's fastest rapper NoClue raps 14.1 syllables per second.<|endoftext|>Korean rappers invented a new type of freestyle, it's called "compliment battle."<|endoftext|>Really, do they do compliments?<|endoftext|>I don't know, but I am visiting Korea in a few, so maybe I will find out.

source: Did you see Crazy Rich Asians? <|endoftext|>No I haven't. I heard it was good. <|endoftext|>I have not yet either but I am aware of its cultural impact. It was made from a novel. Apparently it is a very good romantic comedy. <|endoftext|>My mother liked it. I think it stars Michelle Yeoh, Henry Golding and Constance Wu, right? <|endoftext|>It does. Apparently the basic premise is that a woman is engaged to a man and when she goes to meet his family discovers that he is insanely wealthy. What do you know about it? <|endoftext|>I think that it is a reminder of books that have been banned in the past for their controversial content, I remember it during my childhood <|endoftext|>Aren't most of those books now bestsellers? I see the point of the event, but maybe it should be renamed to better reflect their current status<|endoftext|>Yes, I think you're right, how often do you go to the library btw? <|endoftext|>Not very often since most of what I borrow through my library are ebooks and audiobooks. I love that I can access things right on my phone, though I do miss the feel of paper books.
context: The Sacramento Public Library started a "Library of Things" earlier this year, allowing patrons to check out, among other things, sewing machines and other items that patrons may find useful, but don't need to own long-term.

source: Did you know that the sun takes up 99.86% of the mass of the solar system? Really large, huh? <|endoftext|>That is interesting. Gigantic. The sun is actually white, only perceived as yellow because of atmospheric scattering<|endoftext|>Never knew that. The sun, though, is only 1 billionth the size of the biggest star discovered in our galaxy even though so massive<|endoftext|>That's crazy!! Also, on July 11th, 2011, Neptune completed its first full orbit around the sun since its discovery in 1846... What a slow orbiting planet! <|endoftext|>Wow. I wonder who sits and stares to figure this out. <|endoftext|>Right! It's really interesting though. Facts I never knew about, I'm learning so much from these chats. <|endoftext|>Yes, fun stuff. One lightning bolt is hotter than the surface of the sun 5x hotter. <|endoftext|>That's insane, can't imagine what those people that have been struck by lightning felt like, eek. <|endoftext|>Really burnt unfortunately, may lose limbs from all that energy<|endoftext|>Crazy! Do you like books? When you zoom into the White House on Google Maps, you can see Barack Obama<|endoftext|>Really? I like books a bunch but like exercise too. Reading is a complex brain process decoding symbols into meaning when you think about it. Challenging for some. <|endoftext|>Do you speed read? The world record for speed reading is held by Anne Jones, with a reading speed of 4,700 words per minute<|endoftext|>Not really, but I'm pretty fast so maybe?? I wouldn't know how you tell. Reading can be an escape for some but different for different people how they see things or don't see things.
context: C.S. Lewis and Tolkien held "You Laugh, You Lose" competitions when reading terrible poetry.

source: Did you know that Facebook and Twitter work together on some issues? They are actually competitors.<|endoftext|>No, I didn't know that. What kind of issues do they work together on?<|endoftext|>The babysitter-rating system broke the social networks' rules.
context: Facebook and Twitter are taking action against an automated babysitter-rating system reported on last week by The Washington Post, saying the service broke the social networks' rules on user surveillance and data privacy. Predictim, a California-based start-up, analyzes babysitters' online histories, including on Facebook and Twitter, and offers ratings of whether they are at risk of drug abuse, bullying, or having a bad attitude. Facebook said it dramatically limited Predictims access to users' information on Instagram and Facebook a few weeks ago for violating a ban on developers' use of personal data to evaluate a person for decisions on hiring or eligibility. Facebook spokeswoman Katy Dormer said the company also launched an investigation earlier this week into Predictims extraction, or scraping, of personal data. That investigation is ongoing and could include further penalties. Twitter spokesman Nick Pacilio said the site conducted its own investigation earlier this week and revoked Predictims access to important site toolsknown as Application Programming Interfaces, or APIsthat would allow the start-up to review and analyze babysitters' tweets on a massive scale. "We strictly prohibit the use of Twitter data and APIs for surveillance purposes, including performing background checks," Pacilio said. The crackdown, which was first reported by BBC News, could restrict Predictims ability to analyze babysitters with what it called advanced artificial intelligence and sell parents the results. The service was heavily criticized for offering unproven and potentially inaccurate results that could affect a babysitters life. But Predictims executives said Tuesday they were undeterred and intend to continue pulling publicly available data from Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Predictim Chief Executive and Co-founder Sal Parsa said he also believed the social media giants' reaction was at least partially rooted in a competitive rivalry over personal data use. Twitter and Facebook are already mining our data.

"We strictly prohibit the use of Twitter data and APIs for surveillance purposes, including performing background checks," Pacilio said. The crackdown, which was first reported by BBC News, could restrict Predictims ability to analyze babysitters with what it called advanced artificial intelligence and sell parents the results. The service was heavily criticized for offering unproven and potentially inaccurate results that could affect a babysitters life. But Predictims executives said Tuesday they were undeterred and intend to continue pulling publicly available data from Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Predictim Chief Executive and Co-founder Sal Parsa said he also believed the social media giants' reaction was at least partially rooted in a competitive rivalry over personal data use. Twitter and Facebook are already mining our data.

system_output: Oh, man, can't imagine a concert being so bad you get sued by the audience members... Guessing maybe they had mechanical problems, or one of the band members wasn't performing very well. I recall news of a concert (not Creed, can't recall who it was) where the guy was drunk on stage, and slurred through his songs. They ended up refunding the audience's money...
source: So, I'm reading the latest film from Studio Ghibli is out - The Tale of Princess Kaguya. Dunno if you're familiar with them, but Studio Ghibli has made a lot of great animated films, like Spirited Away, and Princess Mononoke.<|endoftext|>I don't think I have heard of them. I have heard that one of the directors recently passed away, and his last film was nominated for an Academy Award.<|endoftext|>Yeah, sadly, Disney (which owns the American rights to the films) doesn't tend to promote them very much. I think they're worried they'll cut into their "homegrown" market. Anyway, dunno if you even like animated movies, but they're worth checking out.<|endoftext|>I don't watch them very often. Apparently, there was a showing of the recent film in a park in D.C. That's one U.S. city I haven't been to.<|endoftext|>Sadly, I haven't been to DC either, although I've always wanted to visit there. Apparently, there's a lot of interesting things going down this summer. They're having a crab feast at the Navy-Marine Corps Stadium. They'll have 100 gallons of crab soup! Can you imagine that much soup?<|endoftext|>I recently met a girl who lives in that area, and she said the nightlife is worth visiting for. It sounds like many of the events feature jazz music. Do you listen to jazz very often?<|endoftext|>A little bit, I'm not too familiar with it. I know it originated in New Orleans and a little bit about the history, but that's about it. Heard Clint Eastwood is a big jazz fan, thought that was pretty interesting...<|endoftext|>There are many different styles, probably derived from the various regions in the US where it has taken root. Kansas City is another place where it has prominence.<|endoftext|>You know there's a programming language in which programs are written in musical composition, and so the programs have jazz-like harmonies. As a computer guy, I find that pretty fascinating. So, have you ever been to a live concert? (Jazz or otherwise?)<|endoftext|>That is interesting. I have heard that one of the directors recently passed away, and his last film was nominated for an Academy Award.<|endoftext|>Yeah, sadly, Disney (which owns the American rights to the films) doesn't tend to promote them very much. I think they're worried they'll cut into their "homegrown" market. Anyway, dunno if you even like animated movies, but they're worth checking out.<|endoftext|>I don't watch them very often. Apparently, there was a showing of the recent film in a park in D.C. That's one U.S. city I haven't been to.<|endoftext|>Sadly, I haven't been to DC either, although I've always wanted to visit there. Apparently, there's a lot of interesting things going down this summer. They're having a crab feast at the Navy-Marine Corps Stadium. They'll have 100 gallons of crab soup! Can you imagine that much soup?<|endoftext|>I recently met a girl who lives in that area, and she said the nightlife is worth visiting for. It sounds like many of the events feature jazz music. Do you listen to jazz very often?<|endoftext|>A little bit, I'm not too familiar with it. I know it originated in New Orleans and a little bit about the history, but that's about it. Heard Clint Eastwood is a big jazz fan, thought that was pretty interesting...<|endoftext|>There are many different styles, probably derived from the various regions in the US where it has taken root. Kansas City is another place where it has prominence.<|endoftext|>You know there's a programming language in which programs are written in musical composition, and so the programs have jazz-like harmonies. As a computer guy, I find that pretty fascinating. So, have you ever been to a live concert? (Jazz or otherwise?)<|endoftext|>That is interesting. I haven't been to a live concert recently, but I went to many when I was younger. Most of them were in smaller venues though.<|endoftext|>It's been a while since I've been to any as well. Got a friend of mine, he's big into the Ramones and seen them in concert a few times. Get this, they've played a total of 2,263 concerts, touring almost non-stop for over twenty years. Now that's dedication to your music!<|endoftext|>I can only imagine how exhausting that must be as well. Sometimes I think it would be cool to travel to some of the ancient amphitheaters to see what they're like. Pink Floyd once recorded a live concert with no audience in a Roman one in Pompeii.<|endoftext|>Wonder why they did it without an audience? Pretty sure people would have shown if they'd heard about it. Must be one of those "eccentric rock and roll musician" things. Wonder how a concert would sound held in an old amphitheater...<|endoftext|>It might be because an audience would affect the sound and acoustics in the theater. There's another ancient amphitheater in Croatia that's used for concerts. Those Romans really liked their theaters.<|endoftext|>Well, theaters were a big event at the time, plays, gladiator events, concerts... You gotta remember, they didn't have the internet back then, so they had to do something for entertainment. :) So, what was the last concert you ever attended?<|endoftext|>Now that I think about it, I went to one a little over a year ago around Christmastime, so most of the songs were Christmas songs. The venue was fairly big, but not as big as ones like where the big-name artists perform. It was good still, unlike the 2002 Creed concert that was bad enough for concert-goers to file a lawsuit.
context: In 2002, a Creed concert was so bad that four concert-goers filed a lawsuit against the band.

Kansas City is another place where it has prominence.<|endoftext|>You know there's a programming language in which programs are written in musical composition, and so the programs have jazz-like harmonies. As a computer guy, I find that pretty fascinating. So, have you ever been to a live concert? (Jazz or otherwise?)<|endoftext|>That is interesting. I haven't been to a live concert recently, but I went to many when I was younger. Most of them were in smaller venues though.<|endoftext|>It's been a while since I've been to any as well. Got a friend of mine, he's big into the Ramones and seen them in concert a few times. Get this, they've played a total of 2,263 concerts, touring almost non-stop for over twenty years. Now that's dedication to your music!<|endoftext|>I can only imagine how exhausting that must be as well. Sometimes I think it would be cool to travel to some of the ancient amphitheaters to see what they're like. Pretty sure people would have shown if they'd heard about it. Must be one of those "eccentric rock and roll musician" things. Wonder how a concert would sound held in an old amphitheater...<|endoftext|>It might be because an audience would affect the sound and acoustics in the theater. There's another ancient amphitheater in Croatia that's used for concerts. You gotta remember, they didn't have the internet back then, so they had to do something for entertainment. :) So, what was the last concert you ever attended?<|endoftext|>Now that I think about it, I went to one a little over a year ago around Christmastime, so most of the songs were Christmas songs.
